Nom du répondant : Ogwang 
Prénom du répondant : Boby 
email : boby@marulaagribusiness.com 
 
Nom de la structure : Marula Agribusiness Ltd (Online Brand: ProTeen) 
Pays d'origine : Uganda 
Pays d'activité : Uganda 
Site internet : http://www.weareproteen.com 
Linkedin : https://www.linkedin.com/company/weareproteen/ 
 
Présentation de la structure 
Marula Agribusiness Ltd, a daughter company of the Dutch-based Marula Agribusiness B.V. (registered under the Netherlands Chamber of Commerce ), known as ProTeen, is a fully circular, closed-loop waste management system that generates value from organic waste. We use a natural resource, the Black Soldier Fly Larvae, to process the organic waste into high quality animal feed and organic fertilizer. 
We do this through repurposing warehouses and distributing Do-it-Yourself (DIY) Kits to youth. After a successful prototype of our innovation at our Farm at the Makerere Research Institute,  we are entering our first  490m2 Warehouse which was built by the World Bank for the local municipality, the Kampala Capital City Authority (KCCA). In this warehouse, we will process 900T of organic waste per month, all of which is diverted from the Kiteezi landfill. Together with KCCA we aim to process at least 25% of the city’s waste by 2025, an ambitious target for a city that is growing at 5.6% p.a. with an expected annual GDP growth rate of 8%. Simultaneously, Our Protein feed is 10-23% more cost efficient than alternatives on the market, and can be fed to fish, pigs and chickens. Making farming more profitable, efficient and sustainable throughout Africa. 
The unique aspect of our business is that we are a waste management company as well as a protein and fertilizer provider. This innovative business model is rapidly scalable and addresses key urban planning and food security problems of the 21st century. With our 'City Farms' (warehouses) we will supply the large tilapia farms that are populating Lake Victoria. Our DIY Kits will be distributed to existing poultry farmers who will be able to increase their livestock yield by lowering the cost of feed; the cost accounts for at least 80% of their total costs.

Our vision: Cleaning Cities. Employing the Future. Feeding Millions. 
We are driven by the fact that we can repurpose city waste whilst employing youth to revolutionize food systems. 

The Board of Directors is comprised of four international co-founders with diverse backgrounds, Tommie Hooft, Ludivine Berouard, Boby Ogwang and Philipp Straub. Combined the board has lived and worked in Nigeria, Mauritius, South Africa, Thailand, China, France, Germany, The Netherlands, Czech Republic, Kenya and Uganda. Together they combine expertise in Agribusiness and Civil Engineering, Agricultural Sciences and Biosystems Engineering, Doing business and Agriculture in Uganda and East-Africa, as well as  Sustainability. 
Ludivine Berouard, originally from Bordeaux, is a recent Msc graduate of Sustainability and Social Innovation at HEC Paris. This has strengthened our link to France, as we incubated our start-up at Station F for four months. Because of our link to France we continue to have the opportunity to share our ideas such as the team's recent Ted X Talk. It also grew our base of mentors, alumni and potential investors to scale up across Africa. 
 
Présentation du produit, de la solution phare porté par la structure 
Service 1: Organic waste management. 
There is over 1,400t of waste in Kampala per day and over 80% of it is organic waste. Uncollected waste (60%) remains in the city and causes health and environmental problems whilst all the collected waste (40%) is dumped in the Kiteezi landfill, which causes environmental pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. We provide the city with a more efficient and circular solution. Our model reduces 70% of greenhouse gases created by waste that would otherwise be sent to landfill. We offer the government a Hyper-local waste disposal method. Based in Wankoko, Kampala we are in the heart of the city. This cuts down on the city’s overhead costs, as they currently transport waste from the city center to Kiteezi landfill, located 15km away. Moreover, the city’s primary landfill covers a staggering 36 acres of land outside of Kampala. By providing a space efficient solution, we valuable land that is essential for Kampala. By processing the organic waste with the help of Black Soldier Flies, the pathogenic hazard of the waste itself is reduced,  significantly reducing the count of dangerous bacteria such as E. coli or salmonella.

Product 1: Insect Protein Meal. 
Our dried insect larvae is sold as a protein component for animal feed. A protein content of 60% can be reached with a very favorable amino-acid profile, hence our protein quality is comparable to high-quality fishmeal protein. It offers farmers a minimum of 10-23% cost savings when compared to alternative protein sources. It is perfectly suitable for fish, poultry and pigs. It improves the immune response of chickens, increases bird weight by 10%, and improve the quality of eggs significantly. Thanks to a circular and large-scale production process, our insect meal uses a fraction of the land, water or energy needed to produce conventional animal feed. We are revolutionizing current food systems into sustainable food production systems, we also directly help maintain ecosystems by reducing overfishing of silverfish, current source of animal feed. 

Product 2: Organic Fertilizer. 
The most voluminous by-product of the rearing process is decomposed organic waste, which is sold as valuable organic fertilizer. Currently, only 2% of the arable land in Uganda is fertilized. A Ugandan farmer is required to pay twice as much for a bag of fertilizer than a European or US American farmer. Furthermore, the quality of the available fertilizer is extremely low. A study has found that the nutrient content in fertilizers sold in Uganda is on average 20% lower than indicated, mainly due to falsified claims. We offer a sustainable and affordable fertilizer option for farmers and agriculture conglomerates. The fertilizer is more nutrient rich than alternative fertilizers, and improves the characteristics of the soil in a sustainable way. Our organic fertilizer increases the productivity of farmers and strengthens their capacity for adaptation to climate change. 
 
Sur quel marché et vers quelle cible 
Governments: Waste production will increase threefold in developing countries by 2050. Currently, 69% of organic waste in Sub-Saharan Africa is dumped in landfills or burned, accounting for nearly half of all carbon emissions. We provide a safe and toxic-free way to compost waste at scale for governments.
Waste Suppliers: We provide waste suppliers with a clean and convenient solution at a lower price. 

Feed mixers, Poultry farmers, Piggery farmers, Aquaculture farmers: Direct customers buy our products at farm/warehouse gate and indirect customers benefit from our protein included in full Animal Feed products. We ensure that customers can learn about the sustainability benefits of our products at all times, which includes training open to all at our farm every Wednesday. 
 
Zone géographique de l’activité 
We have a farm located in Gayaza, Uganda at the Makerere Research Institute, that produces 2T of fresh larvae per month as well as a 490m2 warehouse operating in Wankoko, Kampala. Both target the greater Kampala Metropolitan Area, for both waste management and product usage. 
Landfills in Kampala are reaching capacity. There exist mechanisms for plastic waste and e-waste management. However, 80% of Kampala’s waste is organic and currently discarded without recovering its nutrients. This mismanagement of waste gravely impacts the quality of life of city residents. The Kampala Capital City Authority transports 28,000 tons of waste to the Kiteezi landfill, which costs the government $3 million in waste management annually. A cost which is poised to rise, as Kampala is the 13th fastest growing city in the world and construction on a second landfill  has already commenced.  This is why we aim to sort 25% of Kampala's organic waste by 2025. Selling our products across Central Uganda. 
 
Objectifs de croissance et vision à moyen et long terme du marché 
Within the next two years, we aim to expand Gulu and Mbarara, two growing cities in Uganda with our replicable and scalable warehouse system.  
In the long-term we aim to target growing cities throughout East Africa and Africa, offering a cost effective, sanitary, sustainable and circular waste management solution.
Through our expansion plans and scalable solution we will support positive economic, social and environmental links between urban, peri-urban and rural areas.Our solution will substantially reduce waste generation and damage through recycling organic waste into valuable products. Our products are aimed to achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture. By majorly hiring and up-skilling youth, we substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment. 
All in all, we are able to drastically reduce the emissions of current processes by offering a sustainable and zero-waste solution that is also cheaper for all our clients and beneficiaries. Ensuring that our solution makes sense for the business and the planet. 
 
En quoi votre solution est elle innovante 
Our solution is innovative as it gives a second life and adds value to organic waste, which otherwise would lie in landfills creating damage to surrounding communities and the planet. Whilst black soldier flies are starting to be used in several countries, especially in Europe, Asia and North America, our solution has been developed specifically for the African context in an easily replicable and scalable solution. We can repurpose any empty warehouse into a waste to protein and fertilizer process. Moreover, we are working on technologies to make our own energy and plastic crates out of recycled plastic bottles to have an entire circular factory. 
 
En quoi est elle duplicable à moindre coût 
We are a young start-up that got a subsidy from the Dutch Government, because of the nature of the subsidy, we were restricted and not allowed to make profit - the subsidy was used to develop our innovation which included testing multiple sources of waste, improving on our supply and value chain, training over 30 local youth from primary graduates to university graduates, developing a training and safety guide etc. Because of this we have been able to perfect our process to the Ugandan context, in a manner that is replicable and low-cost as we plan to expand across Africa. We have just finished our subsidy and have now received investment to scale. 
 
En quoi votre solution rend les villes françaises et africaines plus durables du point de vue environnemental et social 
Our solution has the potential to transform the waste management system in Africa for organic waste, whilst revolutionizing the current way fish, poultry and pigs are fed both in Africa and France. Areas of forest are destroyed every day to grow crops to feed animals, including soy production, a particular harmful production, used to feed our poultry, fish and pigs. In Uganda, overfishing has caused 'silverfish' to become scarce, of low quality and of highly fluctuating prices. Insect protein is a sustainable alternative to soy and fishmeal today's main source of protein. Through such a circular method we can revolutionize today's food systems into sustainable food production. 
 

##################
Nom du répondant : Raheem 
Prénom du répondant : Aishat 
email : aisha.raheem@farmz2u.co.uk 
 
Nom de la structure : Farmz2U 
Pays d'origine : Nigeria 
Pays d'activité : Nigeria 
Site internet : https://www.farmz2u.com/ 
Linkedin : https://www.linkedin.com/in/aisha-raheem-bolarinwa-imc-cima-5294171b/ 
 
Présentation de la structure 
Farmz2U's mission is to help Sub Saharan African farmers farm better with tailored agricultural expertise and access to market. 
Our objectives of food sustainability and economic empowerment for farmers are aligned with the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (UN SDGs). For instance, we support UN SDG 3 by ensuring farmers adopt best farming practices; like fertilizer microdosing to reduce the use of chemicals which decreases the nutritional content of food. And UN SDG 12 by increasing production value through automated workflows and reduced post-harvest waste, with is currently 37% in Sub Saharan Africa. 
Through tests with Nigerian farmers we identified the key challenges our target users (smallholder farmers) face including; post-harvest waste, sub-optimal output yields, weather variability, low technical skills, and  pest and disease outbreaks. Furthermore, we found a lack of gender equality among farmers. This is consistent with the Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development’s report which stated that “women supply 70% of agricultural labour, 50% of animal husbandry related activities and 60% of food processing yet have access to only 20% of available agricultural resources”. Some of the key challenges women face in agriculture are; lack of technological know-how, inadequate finances, lack of land ownership rights, high rate of illiteracy, religious and cultural beliefs, and inadequate resources (Guardian Data Desk, 2017). We manage this challenge through women and youth empowerment groups dedicated to increasing gender diversity and social inclusion in agriculture.
Furthermore, farmers are not protected and earn inequitable returns. For instance, while West African farmers contributed two thirds of the world’s cocoa bean supply, they earned less than 1% from the $50 billion-dollar cocoa industry in 2018 (MarketWatch). 
The problems we are solving are aligned with the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (UN SDGs). For instance, we support UN SDG 3 by ensuring farmers adopt best farming practices; like fertilizer microdosing to reduce the use of chemicals which decreases the nutritional content of food. And UN SDG 12 by increasing production value through automated workflows and minimizing post-harvest waste, currently 37% in Sub Saharan Africa (FAO, 2011).
While our operations are based in Nigeria, our vision is to empower smallholder farmers across Sub Saharan Africa. Our relationship with the African Union (AU) following our recognition as a leading African Diaspora CIDO SME supports the development of local relationships across the continent. For instance, we have memorandum of understanding (MoU) agreements with private and public organizations in Ghana, Kenya and Uganda. 
 
Présentation du produit, de la solution phare porté par la structure 
At Farmz2U we designed a software as a service (SaaS) platform that digitizes the farmer’s value chain, from pre-planting to buyer distribution, while providing tailored agricultural expertise and access to market. With hardware like soil sensors and drones, we collect data on variables like; soil nutrient levels and pest activity. This feeds into the software thus improving the farmer’s decision-making through automated workflows. For instance, a farmer can be instructed to apply 5-10 lbs. of sulfur per 1000 square feet of the farm if data suggests alkaline soil pH levels. And with the field level data generated we have blockchain enabled food traceability which will increase farmers’ appeal to sustainable buyers. For instance, DIAGEO is a buyer with whom we have an NDA with a view to establishing an MoU for procuring farmers’ harvested produce. Our objectives are aligned with UN SDG 3 and 12; ‘ensuring good health and wellbeing’ and ‘enabling responsible production and consumption’. Farmz2U’s long-term goal is to enable end-to-end food traceability from the producer to the end-consumer, with an initial focus on the farmer’s value chain.
Our prototype has been tested by 660 users including farmers and stakeholders like; the FADAMA World Bank sponsored project and DIAGEO. We have incorporated feedback from these beta tests into product development in preparation for our soft market launch in March 2020. To gain user feedback on product development we also share proposed designs with our WhatsApp group of 250 ‘super users’ to validate the need(s) being addressed thus avoiding feature designs nobody wants.
Providing tailored agricultural insights, guaranteeing sales and supporting farmers’ entire value chain is our value proposition to users and the rationale to use Farmz2U instead of competitive or substitute products. Our solution employs technologies like; data analytics and blockchain, in innovative ways. For instance, we use historic crop yields to predict what should be grown and estimate potential output. Similarly, we use Hyperledger enabled blockchain to assess farmers’ credit rating and provide capital options; like NISARL grants and microfinance loans. This also ensures transparency with the distribution of finance to farmers. In addition to our application of existing technologies, we developed a unique method through which consumer data is used to support farmers’ production planning for which a patent was filed in October 2019. 
 
Sur quel marché et vers quelle cible 
While currently based in Nigeria, Farmz2U’s solution aims to benefit farmers across Sub Saharan Africa. Apart from the similarity of soil composition and culture, farmers experience similar challenges. This is evidenced with research like the World Economic Forum 2016 report and user surveys by the Farmz2U team. According to the World Bank, the value of agriculture and agribusiness in Africa will be $1 trillion in 2030, which represents our total addressable market. The value of farming management solutions, the sector in which we operate, is $60 billion and represents our serviceable addressable market (SAM). And the value of the serviceable obtainable market (SOM) our current operational base, Nigeria, is $1 billion. The SAM and SOM estimates are calculated using sector estimates from AgFunder adjusted for local markets. The size of the market creates a significant opportunity for delivering impact.
We delivered benefits through our work with farmers during proof of market (POM) tests; output yields were increased by up to 80% with better practices from automated workflows. We also supported Jute leaf farmers with a pest infestation with the use of broadcast spacing and fertilizer microdosing. The traction made from POM tests supports ongoing negotiations with the FADAMA World Bank sponsored project to finalize a memorandum of understanding to support its 45,000 farmers with our solution. An additional benefit with our solution is a better quality of life for farmers. For instance, through automated monitoring of farm fields to control pests and diseases, farm waste is reduced thus increasing income generation for farmers. Furthermore, through tailored fertilizer application based on accurate soil nutrient levels on the farm, produce yield can be increased while maximizing farm resources. We also have a Public Private Partnership agreement with the University of Uyo (UniUyo) to increase youth participation in agriculture. 
 
Zone géographique de l’activité 
Farmz2U exists because despite Sub Saharan Africa having half of the world’s fertile and as-yet-unused land it spends US$25 billion annually on food imports (WEF, 2015). And despite years of aid our target users, who represent 80% of farmers in the region (NEPAD, 2012), struggle to achieve commercial scale. Through market tests with farmers, we identified their key challenges and address these by providing data enabled insights that support farm operations while enabling stakeholder access. 
According to the World Bank, 25% of the global population is predicted to be in Africa by 2050. This means continued reliance on food importation is unsustainable particularly given the challenges of soil degradation in advanced agricultural economies. 
 
Objectifs de croissance et vision à moyen et long terme du marché 
We are focused on increasing impact across Sub Saharan African because apart from the similarity in soil composition and culture, farmers experience similar challenges. We aim to expand from South West Nigeria, to all zones across the country within 18 months. Thereafter we aim to expand into three Sub Saharan African countries (targets: Ghana, Kenya and Madagascar) within 3 years. This is in line with our 5-year growth plan to increase our userbase to 50,000 farmers with $15 million in annual revenue. 
As a mobile enabled SaaS solution, the cost of entering new markets is low thus ensuring we can increase impact quickly. Furthermore, our local relationships across the continent through collaborative projects with academia and the private sector supports our regional growth strategy.
We are currently in a 2-year growth plan with an initial seed investment of $500,000 and we have the following targets:
-	Userbase of 2,000 farmers and revenue of $100,000
-	Increase farmers’ average produce yields from 33% of global yields to 60%
-	Partner with 10 or more Universities to increase youth engagement in agriculture 
-	Ensure 25% gender equality increase, measurable by resource accessibility in target regions
-	Increase fertilizer use from 17kg/hectare to 135kg/hectare (global average) in target regions 
Our 5-year growth plan has the following targets
-	Userbase of 10,000 farmers and revenue of $1.2 million
-	Increase farmers’ average produce yields to 75% of global yields
-	Expand to at least 3 other countries in Sub Saharan Africa
-	Facilitate gender neutral and fair resource distribution between farmers 
-	Increase fertilizer use to 84kg/hectare in target regions 
 
En quoi votre solution est elle innovante 
Our solution’s scope of digitizing farm operations using software and swarm robotics demonstrates the incorporation of IoT and digital technologies. This is a commercial and technical innovative approach in increasing the value of production in agriculture. 
The core product, a SaaS platform, digitizes farmers’ processes with the aim of automating and improving decision making. For instance, if a farmer needs insight on what to grow, we use historic crop yields and satellite data to suggest the produce likely to have the highest yield given available resources and external trends. We work with local and international data sources to estimate historic crop yields, and the G4AW network to provide satellite data. 
Swarm robotics is a technology concept that took off in the early 2000s (World Economic Forum, 2019). And while not widely used in agriculture there is evidence of its impact on arable farm sizes and structures. Machines like soil sensors and drones and work in a decentralized way to complete specific tasks. For instance, we have a drone that scans the field for pest activity and another that scans the field to estimate the potential produce output. 
 
En quoi est elle duplicable à moindre coût 
Our core solution is a mobile-first offline first platform. Firstly, with an 87% mobile phone penetration rate in Nigeria (Jumia Nigeria, 2018), we are able to access a significant the number of farmers quickly. Furthermore, an offline-first design limits reliance on internet connectivity thus ensuring farmers can access the core features of the solution without constant internet access. This is a similar feature with most countries in Sub Saharan Africa. Secondly as a mobile based solution farmers can easily access the solution further ensuring lower replication costs. Our growth strategy for the Farmz2U solution to new regions limits product design changes to administrative features like language. Core features like best farming practices to apply or data feeds used to predict product yields remain unchanged. 
 
En quoi votre solution rend les villes françaises et africaines plus durables du point de vue environnemental et social 
Farmz2U’s objective is to create sustainable food systems with more efficient resource use using data analytics and swarm robotics. Some challenges with current food systems include; greenhouse gas emissions from farm activities (10% of global emissions, Eurostat), agricultural intensification from chemical and pesticide use, contaminated water systems from excess nutrients (eutrophication) and food waste (1/3 of global production, FAO) from overproduction. 
Our aim is to help farmers farm better with tailored agricultural expertise and access to market. These are aligned with the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (UN SDGs). For instance, we support UN SDG 3 by ensuring farmers adopt best farming practices; like fertilizer microdosing to reduce the use of chemicals which decreases the nutritional content of food. And UN SDG 12 by increasing production value through automated workflows and reduced post-harvest waste, currently 37% in Sub Saharan Africa (FAO, 2011).
From our work with farmers, we increased the adoption of fertiliser microdosing which reduces the negative impact of chemicals on the soil. Furthermore, drone monitoring of farm fields to identify pest and disease activity helped curb infestations. This reduced farmers post-harvest loss from an average of 60% to 30%. In addition, the introduction of vertical farming on a farm estate, Amuludun, where each farmer owned 2.5 acres of land increased output and adoption of best practices.

Nom de la structure : SOCIETE DES ACTION GENERALES AU CONGO 
Pays d'origine : France 
Pays d'activité : Congo-Kinshasa 
Site internet : http://www.sogeckinsha.com 
Linkedin : nan 
 
Présentation de la structure 
1.	Présentation de Société des Action Générale au Congo
SOGEC est une société implantée au Congo ;  est une organisation de droits Congolais, implantée dans la ville de Kindu en Province du Maniema  en République Démocratique du Congo. 
SAGEC a été créée pour contribuer à apporter des réponses aux défis socioculturels et économiques, sanitaire du peuple congolais en RDC. Pour cette fin, SAGEC intervient dans différents domaines économique et autres :
o	Promotion de l’agriculture durable en facilitant la production et la commercialisation de productions agricoles (agro-business);
o	Construction ;
o	Rendre opérationnelles des équipes d’urgences mobilisables compétentes et capable d’apporter une assistance humanitaire, sur tout le continent africain en général et le territoire congolais en particulier, cas d’épidémies, catastrophes ou conflits ;
o	sensibiliser la population surtout la jeunesse à l’agropastoral, à la protection de l’environnement, à la promotion de la paix, à travers l’apprentissage des métiers notamment la coupe-couture, la maçonnerie, la menuiserie et à la sécurité alimentaire … ;
o	Réhabiliter et entretenir les routes et les autres infrastructures de base ;
o	Sensibiliser les  populations à l’auto-prise en charge à travers l’installation de la mutuelle de santé,  du système de recyclage des déchets (Transport et décharge des déchets selon les normes)  et de gestion des pluies ;
o	Inciter les jeunes à l’autopromotion socio-économique et culturelle, l’encadrement technique et l’animation conscientisant ;
o	Promotion la santé communautaire et lutter contre les MST et VIH/SIDA;
 L’organisation a son bureau de coordination à Kindu, dans la province du Maniema, au N°11, Av. INGA N  et est représentée au numéro 20 avenue Bosango Commune Masina ville de Kinshasa. 

Pour un leadership futur  Jeunes, SOGEC encadre les clubs de jeunes (filles et garçons) pour leur éducation préventive au leadership.      

SOGEC  fonctionne en RDC sous l’identité Nationale 5-450-N15849-G et RCC-M KND/RCCM/14-B-476. 

SOGEC a les Statuts et un règlement d'ordre intérieur notariés et légalisés par les autorités  nationales compétentes. Sa gestion financière, administrative et logistique  est orientée par le Manuel de Procédure Administrative et Financière (MAPAF). 

2.	Vision et mission :
<U+F076>	Sa vision : est de réduire l’extrême pauvreté et rétablir la dignité humaine  pour un Congo émergent en développant l’agriculture, en facilitant une urbanisation juste
Sa mission 
-	Faire de l’agriculture urbaine une préoccupation marginale pour combattre l’insécurité 
-	est  d’apporter un appui technique et financier aux jeunes et aux femmes afin de les aider à combattre contre la pauvreté et la discrimination. 



3.	Objectifs :
o	Promouvoir et accompagner les actions de développement en tenant compte du présent et du futur de l’écosystème ;
o	Promouvoir dans les zones rurales et urbaines des projets locaux pour assurer à toutes les communautés les soins de santé essentie 
 
Présentation du produit, de la solution phare porté par la structure 
1.	La SAGEC est une entreprise qui travaille pour innover. Cette innovation s’oriente vers la mise en œuvre de produits (biens et services) ou ne nouveau procédés prouvant bien attendu amélioré, des nouvelles méthodes de commercialisation et du travail au sein de l’entreprise mais les relations avec extérieur. Cette innovation peut se mesurer en passant pas de méthodes, le fort d’innover et les résultats d’innovation 
Les principales productions de l’agriculture urbaine que la SAGEC veut mettre à la disposition des urbains, seront constituées des légumes (maraichage) et les élevages (Volaille, Porc…) dont les produit utiles sont le lait, viande, les œufs, légumes… 
En supplément en apport protéine animale produite localement pour l’alimentation des urbains, ces petits élevage sont aussi favorables sont favorable aux recyclages des déchets organique alimentaire en passant par le compostage.  Cultiver en ville implique de faire face à plusieurs contrainte telles que : l’optimisation de la place disponible, la maitrise de l’exposition de population au polluant souvent présent dans les différents milieux (Sol eau air.) il est donc nécessaire de réduire l’impact environnemental de ces cultures par le recyclage de matière organique en particulier, afin qu’elles deviennent durable avec des pratique particulièrement pertinente à développer en zone urbaine. 
Face à toutes ces préoccupations, les solutions seraient la mise en place d’un système agricole qui serait l’exacte opposé au modèle actuel ; qui séquestrerait le Gaz à effet de serre (GES), parierait l’eau et le sol, qui serait autosuffisant et permettrai même la création d’écosystème pérenne…  c’est ce modèle connu sous le nom de la permaculture urbaine que la SAGEC propose comme solution, car il constitue l’une de stratégie de préservation de sécurité alimentaire et lutte contre les vulnérabilités de système de production alimentaire face aux effet du changement climatique. 
Ainsi, l’agriculture urbaine est perçue par la SAGEC comme une solution innovatrice pouvant pallier à la crise alimentaire mondiale qui rattrape petit à petit l’humanité dans le mode de production malsain et polluant. 
 
Sur quel marché et vers quelle cible 
Le marché est encore local (National), au fur du temps, notre marché sera régional et plus loin continental avec comme cible, les populations citadines de l’Est de RDC et la ville province de Kinshasa. 
 
Zone géographique de l’activité 
L’activité est plantée à l’Est de la RDC, en province du Maniema, ville de Kindu 
 
Objectifs de croissance et vision à moyen et long terme du marché 
4.	A ce niveau, la mise en place de système alimentaire relisent est une nécessité. Les objectifs de la SAGEC s’oriente dans le sens de :
1.	Diversifier les chaines d’approvisionnement alimentaire en s’appuyant sur les systèmes de production et de distribution alimentaires à grande et petite échelé, en faisant appel à des sources commerciales et communautaire sans être dépendante d’une seule ;
2.	Fournir à tous une alimentation saine, durable, équitable et en quantité suffisante… ;
3.	Puiser dans le flux de déchets (eau usées, déchets ménagers et organique) pour la production alimentaire ;
4.	Créer de synergies en améliorant l’accès à une alimentation sein et la création d’emploi ;
5.	Mettre l’homme au cœur du système alimentaire : d’une part bénéfice accès à une alimentation saine et durable ainsi que l’emploi ; d’autre part il participe activement au système alimentaire entant que citoyen très consommateurs ;
6.	Contribuer à la réduction des émissions des gaz à effet de serre en mettant en place des stratégies locales d’adaptation au changement climatique et d’atténuation des effets ; et afin 
7.	Encourager une gestion de terre efficace et la restauration de sol. 
 
En quoi votre solution est elle innovante 
C’est une innovation par le fait, qu’elle prend compte la dimension sociale, dans le sens où il vient donner solution au problème d’alimentation aux communautés tout en mettant en œuvre le produit « BIO »de qualité et quantité suffisante à un prix abordable. C’est une stratégie qui répond aux enjeux environnementaux du fait que les déchets biodégradables seront utilisés au compost et les déchets non biodégradables seront recyclés. C’est une stratégie qui favorise plusieurs emplois, à la manière des innovations frugales et permet de faire mieux en moindre coup. 
 
En quoi est elle duplicable à moindre coût 
Elle est duplicable par le fait que la SAGEC cherche à mettre en place un processus dans lequel les considérations environnementales, sociales et économiques seront intégrées dans le système d’entreprise. Parce qu’il va partir de l’utilisation de moindre ressources, il possible qu’elle se duplique en plusieurs secteur de production. 
 
En quoi votre solution rend les villes françaises et africaines plus durables du point de vue environnemental et social 
Dans le boom démographique que l’humanité en général et la RDC en particulier fait face, les villes sont caractérisées par les densités des populations élevées, de forte compétition pour l’usage de l’espace et des pollutions fréquemment observées des milieux (Sols, Eaux et Air). Ces caractéristiques ont de conséquence sur les formes de l’agriculture urbaine et la gestion de déchet. Il est donc urgent de trouver les solutions durable d’agriculture urbaine et de lutter contre l’insécurité alimentaire le les effets du changement climatiques. Les villes étant inondées, le système alimentaire urbain se voit menacé. Eu égard à ce qui précède, la SAGEC s’est sentie obligée mettre en place une stratégie de développer une économie élémentaire robuste et de mettre en place différente mesures visant à réduire les vulnérabilités au risque naturels, à créer un système à capacité en long terme de fournir à tous une alimentation saine, durable et quantité suffisante, moins chère, même en cas de stress chronique ou de chocs ponctuels, y compris les circonstances imprévisibles ; tout en mettant en œuvre un système qui, résiste aux perturbations sans mettre en péril la sécurité alimentaire dont les éléments du systèmes sont remplaçable et peuvent absorber les effets de stress ou de chocs ou peut rapidement renouer avec la sécurité alimentaire et s’adapter aux circonstances changeantes. 
 

##################
Nom du répondant : Ndiaye 
Prénom du répondant : Maimouna 
email : GIEdjiguenoutay@gmail.com 
 
Nom de la structure : GIE DjiguenouTay 
Pays d'origine : Sénégal 
Pays d'activité : Sénégal 
Site internet : http://www.yobalema.fr 
Linkedin : nan 
 
Présentation de la structure 
Le GIE est constitué de 37 femmes avec Maimouna Ndiaye à la présidence, Marieme Samb comme secrétaire et Aby Ndiaye comme trésorière. L'activité du GIE portera essentiellement sur un projet agricole générateur de revenus avec la vente de fruits et de légumes produits dans une démarche de qualité biologiques AB. A terme le GIE développera une activité de transformation de ces produits agricoles par séchage et une activité de restauration. Le GIE permettra un changement de production et d’approvisionnement en alimentation du village au travers de la vente et transmettra aux enfants des écoles des savoirs pratiques dans le domaine de l’agro-écologie, du cycle et de la gestion de l’eau ou les énergies renouvelables. Nous serons toutes formées en pratiques agricoles durables telles que la permaculture et l’agro-écologie. La mairie de Yenne nous soutient dans le projet au travers d’une formation en gestion et comptabilité. 
Chaque année, depuis 2009, un séjour est organisé à Kelle, par l’association Yobalema. Ce séjour, loin des itinéraires touristiques habituels a permis de créer un lien fort avec les membres adhérent.e.s de Yobalema.
Un collectif de 11 personnes bénévoles, adhérent.e.s de l’association Yobalema est très actif sur les événements artistiques et culturels ou de demande de subventions au profit du projet Djiguenou Tay. L’association Yobalema n’interviendra pas dans l’organisation et la répartition des actions au sein du collectif de 37 femmes mais sera force de proposition pour le design et l’organisation des éléments structurants du potager tel que le forage, les panneaux photovoltaïques, les locaux, les plantations d’arbres et semis, les clôtures et installations diverses. Les membres adhérents-tes seront présents ponctuellement pour des chantiers participatifs, des actions locales ou des événements festifs autour du potager. 
 
Présentation du produit, de la solution phare porté par la structure 
1) L’extension des villes au détriment de l’espace rural et le développement de pratiques agricoles intensives pour satisfaire la demande alimentaire croissante engendrent des pressions croissantes et continues sur les ressources naturelles qui se dégradent avec une rapidité inquiétante.
2) La demande de production en agriculture biologique (AB) est croissante au Sénégal car les exploitants sont de plus en plus sensibles aux impacts de leurs pratiques sur l’environnement et la santé. 
3) Les systèmes agricoles durables sont plus stables et résilients face au changement climatique.
Ainsi dans ce contexte, le potager DJIGUENOU TAY associant des pratiques de permaculture et d’agro-écologie est garant d’un mode de production durable préservant la bio-diversité naturelle en réponse aux problèmes sanitaires et environnementaux graves posés par l’agriculture intensive. Il s’appuie sur :
•	des systèmes agricoles basés sur des cultures multiples (mélange de cultures légumières, d’arbres, de plantes mellifères ou aromatiques, favoriser la présence d’insectes prédateurs de ravageurs des cultures, d’insectes pollinisateurs et d’oiseaux)
•	le contrôle intégré des insectes et des maladies (faune auxiliaires ravageurs, insectes pollinisateurs, purin de plantes à base de neem, etc.)
•	la diversité génétique avec des variétés anciennes valorisant le patrimoine semencier local, production de graines
•	le maintien naturel de la fertilité du sol (recyclage des nutriments avec le compost – déchets végétaux, coque d’arachide, poisson-, gestion de la matière organique, amélioration de la structure des sols avec l’apport de broyats végétaux, etc.)
•	la gestion de l’eau (goutte à goutte, paillage du sol, réserve d’eau)
Ce projet contribue à répondre aux défis des Objectifs de Développement Durable (ODD)  (2) Lutte contre la faim, (5) Egalité des sexes, (7) Recours aux énergies renouvelables, (11) villes et communautés durables, (12) consommation et production responsables, (13) lutte contre le changement climatique, (15) protection de la faune et la flore terrestres.
Ce projet s’inscrit également dans le plan alimentaire territorial durable du territoire dont fait partie Kelle et dans le Plan Sénégal Emergent (2019-2023), visant à privilégier les exploitations agricoles familiales pour renforcer l’autoconsommation, la résilience des populations face à l’insécurité alimentaire, nutritionnelle et lutter contre l’exode rural.
Dans un environnement coutumier où les décideurs sont essentiellement des hommes, nous pourront non seulement nous approprier de nouveaux savoirs et apporter un complément financier mais aussi devenir des relais locaux de ces nouvelles méthodes de gestion de l’eau et des déchets, d’utilisation des énergies renouvelables, de production agricole durable et résiliente, auprès des enfants et des villageois. 
 
Sur quel marché et vers quelle cible 
Ce projet collectif agricole de femmes, financé avec des fonds publics et de taille adaptée au nombre de femmes, sera le premier sur Kelle. 
1) La production du GIE Djiguenou Tay sera vendu au travers de marchés locaux et de proximité dont le marché biologique « BioDialaw » organisé une fois par mois. 
2) Les habitants de Kelle (plus de 2100 habitants) pourront acheter localement et en direct auprès du GIE. 
3) Les écoles du village sensibilisées à cette agriculture durable et locale pourront acheter les fruits et légumes au potager pour qu’une fois par semaine les élèves puissent rester manger à l’école et travailler sur le bienfait d’une alimentation saine et locale. 
4) A terme, le GIE transformera l’excédent de la production en fruits et légumes et ciblera ainsi le marché de l’agro-alimentaire. En effet, la transformation des produits agricoles occupe une place importante dans l’économie locale et nationale. Bien que la mise en sachet et l’étiquetage apportent une valeur ajoutée aux produits, le conditionnement a, souvent, un coût trop élevé pour les transformatrices. De ce fait, nombreuses sont les femmes qui vendent leurs produits en vrac dans leur réseau de proximité. Il existe réellement un créneau de transformation des produits agricoles frais qui est encore très peu valorisé. Sur des périodes où elles n’auront pas assez de production, elles pourront aller s’approvisionner en fruits et légumes frais directement, auprès d’autres producteurs. 
 
Zone géographique de l’activité 
Kelle (2100 habitants) est situé à 45kms de Dakar sur le territoire de Rufisque et la commune de Yenne et est exclusivement tourné vers l’activité de pêche en pirogue et l’élevage. C’est un département caractérisé par une nappe d’eau souterraine peu profonde, un climat doux, une qualité pédologique et une pluviométrie propices aux cultures maraîchères. Cependant, la pêche reste un secteur fragile et la disparition des exploitations agricoles contribuent à la hausse des prix des produits locaux, un éloignement des marchés locaux et une recrudescence des produits importés. En conséquence, le département de Rufisque souhaite préserver les exploitations agricoles familiales pour renforcer la résilience des populations face à l’insécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle. 
 
Objectifs de croissance et vision à moyen et long terme du marché 
« En Afrique de l’Ouest, les agricultures familiales demeurent largement majoritaires dans la production agropastorale, que celle-ci soit destinée aux marchés locaux ou internationaux. Elles jouent un rôle important dans l’approvisionnement des villes dont le nombre et la taille ne cessent de croître » 
Ce projet « Djiguenou Tay » se donne comme objectif de soutenir la résilience des populations agropastorales ou de pêcheurs face aux chocs récurrents de baisses de revenus auxquels elles font régulièrement face. Ce projet contribue à un développement économique local profitable au plus grand nombre et qui revalorise les métiers agricoles auprès des jeunes pour limiter l’exode rurale ou l’immigration clandestine. 
De plus, les produits importés sont très présents dans l’alimentation et les prix des produits locaux (poisson, légume, viande) ont flambé en l’espace d’une dizaine d’années. 
En conséquence, ces projets de micro-fermes promouvant une agriculture durable et locale vont s’accroitre et s’accompagner de développement de marchés locaux de proximité. Ceci permettra de palier aux besoins en fruits et légumes des villes africaines face à leur croissance de plus de 3% par an en moyenne avec une population urbaine absorbant 70% de la croissance démographique du continent. 
 
En quoi votre solution est elle innovante 
Au travers de pratiques innovantes de Permaculture et d’Agro-écologie, ce projet sera garant d’un mode de production durable pour préserver les ressources naturelles et la biodiversité, protéger l’environnement et lutter ainsi contre les changements climatiques.
Fondée sur l’observation de la nature et des cycles de végétations, la Permaculture permet de recréer un écosystème naturel, permanent et résilient en parfaite harmonie et dans un équilibre tel qu’il nécessite le moins d’interventions humaines possibles. 
L’Agro-écologie permet de concevoir des systèmes agricoles basés sur la valorisation des processus écologiques. 
•	Créer et Préserver la Biodiversité 
•	Créer des Associations Bénéfiques : Céréales et légumineuses, Forêt jardin 
•	Biocontrôle et méthodes de protection des cultures : Régulations biologiques et usage d’organismes ou de produits d’origine naturelle
•	Favoriser les apports naturels en azote, carbone, phosphore, augmenter la matière organique et éviter les pertes en éléments nutritifs et en eau
•	Utiliser les énergies renouvelables comme le soleil ou le vent pour générer de l’électricité
•	Gestion de l’eau
Ce projet d’agriculture familiale est garant d’une écologie appliquée avec une production très diversifiée et rentable. Ce modèle agricole de micro-ferme à l’échelle humaine peut facilement s’étendre sur un territoire, à proximité des villes pour nourrir la communauté et contribuer à l’emploi. 
 
En quoi est elle duplicable à moindre coût 
Le Grdr Migration-Citoyenneté-Développement accompagne des coopératives ou des groupements d’intérêts économiques, principalement composés de productrices ou de jeunes à renforcer leurs capacités à se structurer autour de savoir-faire portés sur l’agro-écologie. Ainsi nous pourront plus facilement échanger et transmettre à d’autres femmes du village et des villages voisins leurs savoirs et renforcer leurs compétences sur des pratiques agricoles durables. A long terme, d’autres GIE vont se former sur cette même dynamique et conforter la structuration des organisations paysanne, ce qui à terme facilitera la création dune dynamique paysanne de mise en commun de connaissances anciennes et nouvelles sur l’agro-écologie. 
Ces GIE pourront s’organiser en réseau pour partager les connaissances et savoir-faire et mutualiser les services en gestion et comptabilité. 
 
En quoi votre solution rend les villes françaises et africaines plus durables du point de vue environnemental et social 
Un enfant sur deux à Dakar ne prend pas son petit-déjeuner avant de venir à l’école et un enfant sur trois souffre de carences en vitamines et nutriments. En conséquence, l’accès à une alimentation-nutrition à l’école pour des enfants issus des milieux défavorisés est envisageable grâce à ces exploitations familiales en périphérie urbaine qui pourront proposer aux cantines des produits sains et locaux. Les écoles pourront travailler sur la saisonnalité des fruits et légumes et sensibiliser les enfants à une alimentation saine et durable axée sur la valorisation des produits locaux au profit de ceux importés et expérimenter de nouvelles saveurs, ouvrant ainsi leur curiosité. 
Cette transmission de valeurs propres au travail de la terre permettra à cette jeunesse de retrouver un attrait et un intérêt dans les exploitations familiales agricoles et devenir des acteurs du changement dans les modes de consommation et de production.
Djiguenou Tay est un projet d’agriculture de micro-ferme à taille humaine sans machinisme avec des techniques de permaculture et d’agro-écologique qui doit être favorisé et qui peut s’étendre en milieu urbain. En effet, ces fermes de petite taille très diversifiées et avec de bons rendements permettront en milieu urbain ou péri-urbain de nourrir la population, d’alimenter les écoles, les restaurants et épiceries de proximité, de générer de l’emploi et de contribuer à un environnement meilleur sans pesticides et plus résilient au changement climatique.

Nom du répondant : Ochieng 
Prénom du répondant : Perez 
email : perez.sacoma@gmail.com 
 
Nom de la structure : SACOMA FOODS AND GLOBAL BUSSINESS INNOVATION 
Pays d'origine : Kenya 
Pays d'activité : United Kingdom 
Site internet : http://www.sacomasweetpotatoes.com 
Linkedin : https://www.linkedin.com/in/perez-ochieng-995a1489/ 
 
Présentation de la structure 
Our Vision is to be a Global market leader and innovator of Kenyan sweet potatoes and products. Our strategic direction it to eventually position the Kenya sweet potato smallholder farmer’s to take up innovations and develop quality sweet potato products as ingredients, composite products and raw materials for New-Product-Development for exports of healthy food products demanded by UK/EU and the global markets.

We  source our products from groups and cooperatives of small holder farmers in Western Kenya (HomaBay , Kericho, Bomet). Around 4000 Farmers in the three counties have been brought together and trained on good agriculture practices in Production of quality sweet potatoes to specified varieties and other derivative products for export markets and in HACCP systems for quality control in processing sweet potato flour.

Impact and Resources available: Over 4000 small holder farmers in organized groups and 5 agri-foods processors within the three counties. Processing and Handling  facilities with capacity to store up to 20 tons of produce; Collection centers; Packing houses; Experienced staff / HR and farmers that understand quality specification; Established marketing team and researchers and technical food scientist and formulators; Marketers and working groups based in the target markets in UK/EU; Knowledge transfer partnership with UK/EU universities for continuous R&D on sweet potato handling, production and market; Network of collaborating industry partners and food manufacturers for product co-creation plus a distribution and retail chain in UK/EU; Intellectual Property (IP) rights and recognized brand; Websites and  wide network of buyers and consumer community; Stakeholder relationship with ministry of trade to develop policies that would  increase Kenya’s export to the UK/EU and other markets 
 
Présentation du produit, de la solution phare porté par la structure 
We export sweet potatoes to a fast-developing consumer market in the UK and also
re-export to other EU countries, Spain and Italy. 
We  sell our own brand of packaged sweet potato fresh roots and packaged food products   in a number of Retail and Distibution chains, supermarkets, shops, restaurant/caterers, Cash & Carry and to directly to the consumers. We also sell the sweet potato flour and puree as ingredients that serves our niche customers working within the Retail, Food Service, Catering, and Speciality Food sectors with quality assured and healthy sweet potato snacks and products. We supply to other EU markekts via distributors and agents and e-commerce platforms.  Ppartnership with i-cloud blending technology in Spanish hub enables our company to launch our products into other markets and countries such as India via de-centralised manufacturing and food disruptive technologies.

Current products: 
Include sweet potato snack bars, crisp, chips, desserts (Crème brulee), meal replacement powders, pancake powders, soup mix, fresh roots, high protein, high-fibre-sweet-potato-seed- crackers and vegetarian/vegan sweet potato burgers and nutritious powder soups. All products are clean-label (made from natural ingredients) with no additives or food colouring. All products in our brand are healthy Natural, Gluten-Free, Non-GMO, Sugar-Free, with Low Glycaemic-Index (GI) and unrefined-carbohydrates, and also rich in essential oils. A category of nutrient-dense food powder and meal replacement products appropriate for people aged over 50 years will be launched in March2019 in UK and EU.
The Unique technology and process: 
Our unique partnership with icloud blending technology, Powder Blending unit is a key element in our technology for decentralized manufacturing model that gives the capability to assure the quality of the finished powder products complete with traceability. This technology is high flexibility that allows us to test new markets with small, quick production batches then adapt products to individual needs, make instant changes in formulation and raw materials and scale production to the demand. These food Powders: Are easy to transport and stock/store; Reduce energy use on cold-chain-logistics, Distribution/Storage; Retain nutritional properties, have longer shelf life and reduce Food waste; Can be customized to meet specific nutrition needs/requirements for individualized diets (Personalized-Nutrition) and Have minimal contamination risk 
 
Sur quel marché et vers quelle cible 
Customers and current buyers consist of UK/EU Retailers, Distributors, food manufacturers, specialty shops, traders, and commission agents targeting food vendors, Restaurants, schools, household consumers, supermarkets, Wholesalers, specialty healthy foods shops/stores, Sports Shops/Centres and online. We have Commitment letters, orders and contracts. 

Current trends and state of the target Market: 
Sweet Potatoes are rising in popularity mainly because of the many health benefits. This trend has a positive impact on the marketing of sweet potatoes. However, although the importation of sweet potatoes into UK/EU has increased, there is still the lack of food products based on sweet potatoes on the European market. Poor dietary choices that lead to an unhealthy diet and a number of individuals affected by obesity related diseases are an increasing public health concern in Europe resulting to food companies responding to changes such as new food labelling regulations and a new breed of health-conscious consumer by reformulating their products. 
Changing consumer habits and tastes are driving rapid change and creating room for new players to disrupt the industry. The purpose of SACOMA- Kenya-sweet-potato initiative is to produce and promote SWEET POTATO Products further boosting the demand for Sweet potatoes combating obesity and malnutrition aimed at improving public health in the target buyer market in Europe as well as economic growth for Kenya farmers 
 
Zone géographique de l’activité 
The global food industry is increasingly looking for new types of dietary fibres for a rich variety of foods, dietary supplements, and even animal feed as there is a strong and growing demand from consumers (Innovation Drivers) for natural solutions for many global consumer groups, “natural dietary fibers” is considered good for health. 
SWEET POTATOES will provide novel business opportunities to actors of the food industry from a global perspective, with a strong potential for new revenues and diversification. The greatest growth opportunity exists in the export markets for kenya small holder farmers to integrate in the supply chain to supply food industry and food manufacturers , who will then distribute to retailers and consumers, working together with farmers to encourage improved quality production and  efficiencies with a focus on ethical trading and consumer needs for healthy, nutritious, affordable and sustainable diets, sustainability, climate compliance  and waste reduction. 
 
Objectifs de croissance et vision à moyen et long terme du marché 
Expansion of consumer and older buyer/consumer base: The Growth opportunities for target market also exist in the supply of food powders and meal replacements, in particular for the growing UK/EU aging population; It is estimated that by the year 2050, the population of UK/EU will 50% people over 50 years and with special dithery needs. We have developed new product ready for launch in March 2019 targeting the order population in the UK/EU. New products have been developed ready for commercialization in line with changing UK/EU consumer trends and demand for high fibre, super foods and essential oils, include sweet potato crackers developed with Supply Novel ingredients such as amaranth to introduce the UK consumers to this type of novel ingredients and in line with the new EU regulations on novel ingredients. 

Expansion of supplier base and increased production:
Sweet potatoes are part of a trending demand for exotic and ethnic food in Europe, with the demand increasing by 12% in recent years in the UK. In total, consumption exceeded 300,000T in 2017. Health issues are an increasing driver of product choice in the EU. This trend has a positive impact on the marketing of sweet potatoes, which are high in vitamins A and C and are considered to be a healthier alternative to regular potatoes. The consumption of sweet potatoes has more than doubled over the recent past and supermarkets are catering to this trend. UK is the leading Importer of sweet potato in Europe, where, along with the Netherlands, sweet potato is considered a conventional product. Both countries offer a fast-developing consumer market. The UK is a typical end market, (re-)exporting much less than the Netherlands. The consumption in these leading countries is a promising sign for future growth in the EU countries.  The orange flesh varieties are the most common in EU and there are two varieties that cover 95% of the market: The American Covington and The Spanish Beauregard.

En quoi votre solution est elle innovante 
Our Innovation: 
Consumers in UK/EU are growing more aware of their eating habits giving more attention to health aspects since life-style related diseases have increased, many of which stem from the excessive intake of unhealthy foods. The food sector faces a number of considerable challenges to develop new and advanced products. Our disruptive food manufacturing and icloud blending innovation offers a solution providing innovative inputs on novel healthy food, analysing food choice and eating habits and the impact of food choice on consumers’ health to provide a Personalised Nutrition (PI) specific to the consumer needs. Our research provides new healthy food products and processes in line with the planned reforms and contributes to quality of life and has the potential to improve lives and provide more jobs within the farming communities. 
 
En quoi est elle duplicable à moindre coût 
We have invested in the scale and pace of uptake of disruptive food innovation through Industry4.0 manufacturing technology to develop and launch more food powder products as per the identified consumer trend and needs. Our goal to stimulate European consumers to select Kenya’s sweet potato and food products that fit into a healthy diet, and then stimulate the Kenya sweet potatoes small holder farmers and sub-sector to increase volumes that will enable for a sustainable production and packaging of healthier premium high-quality sweet potato foods in a safe and affordable way. 
 
En quoi votre solution rend les villes françaises et africaines plus durables du point de vue environnemental et social

Sweet Potatoes are rising in popularity mainly because of the many health benefits. This trend has a positive impact on the marketing of sweet potatoes. However, although the importation of sweet potatoes into UK/EU has increased, there is still the lack of food products based on sweet potatoes on the European market. Changing consumer habits and tastes are driving rapid change and creating room for new players to disrupt the industry. The purpose of SACOMA- Kenya-sweet-potato initiative is to produce and promote SWEET POTATO Products further boosting the demand for Sweet potatoes combating obesity and malnutrition aimed at improving public health in the target buyer market in Europe as well as economic growth for Kenya farmers.

With an increasing global population and a significant increase in living standards around the world, the pressure on natural resources will be intensified over the next decades. Nom du répondant : Vilakazi 
Prénom du répondant : Andile Nkosenhle 
email : andilevila@gmail.com 
 
Nom de la structure : Nakekela Environment Programme 
Pays d'origine : South Africa 
Pays d'activité : South Africa

Présentation de la structure 
Nakekela is very passionate about conserving the environment and believes that community outreach through environmental education bare positive results in bringing awareness and a change in attitude. Ignorance by the community leads to a lack of understanding and appreciating the importance of proper environmental management. Nakelela believes that this can be remedied by the sustained provision of environmental education to the community. We believe that continuous education is crucial in improving the quality of the community and the sustainability of the earth’s finite resources for the future generations.
South Africans has enshrined Constitutional right to an environment that is conducive to the good health, general well-being of all people and one that is protected for the benefit of the present and future generations. The protection of our natural resources ensures the ongoing provision of ecosystem services such as the production of clean water through good catchment management, prevention of soil erosion and the creation of an environment conducive for clean air and that can only be addressed through environmental education and awareness of how those can be sustained. Our actions today have a bearing on the quality of life that future generations will inherit.
As more and more people accept that in the long-term community well-being can be achieved only within the context of a healthy earth community through environmental education, the challenge for us, and the next few generations, is to find novel and practical ways of drawing inspiration from the rich diversity of human experience as well as environmental awareness in order to  establish effective means of changing human behaviour to ensure that they contribute to the flourishing of the whole earth community instead of destroying it.
Active involvement of communities in managing their environment must be a daily activity. Equality, access, accountability, transparency, responsibility and sustainable living must be our watchword. 
 
Présentation du produit, de la solution phare porté par la structure 
Precision Agriculture applied with Organic Crop Protection
My Agricultural experience (five years in the co-operative, academic knowledge in botany) led me to a sustainable organic crop protection concept based on the following five building blocks.
First, it entails plant nutrition. In this concept, organic compost fertilizer and use of earthworms, and plasticulture are combined. Organic compost fertiliser improves soil structure, nutrition in soil, water retention partially due to earthworm activity as they aerate soil. This allows for deeper penetration of water and roots, resulting in healthier plants. Healthy plants are more resistant to diseases as they are not stressed. To improve the soil moisture regime, the use of plasticulture mulching is incorporated, thereby retaining soil moisture, protecting germination of seedlings and prevention of weeds.
Second, it entails organic crop protection for the control of insects that introduce and spread bacterial, fungal and viral diseases. Identification of prevalent diseases and pests for a specific crop, season and location is the basis for selecting appropriate control plants. Planting certain plants and herbs like springs onions, marigold, mint, basil, lavender and rosemary in alternate rows to your crops, cut down insects and bugs damage. Introduction of ladybugs (Coccinellidae septempunctata) that feed off aphids and to other plants eating pests. A single lady beetle can gobble more than 5000 aphids and I consider this a better idea that prevents chemical use. Lady beetles are harmless to plants and humans.
Third, weed control is based on covering the soil with 300 micron plastic that is coloured black on side (facing down) and white on the side facing up. It deprives weeds of light whilst the white reflects light for the crops above as such a multiplier for sunlight and enhanced photosynthesis. Weed control, esp. for bacterial and algal diseases is done through the treating of water with an organic spore kill.
Fourth, the use of a green shade cloth structure for open field vegetables assists in keeping the plants moisture, protect plants from excessive sunrays and storm. Often wind damage to plants is mistaken as thrips and is treated chemically. Wind damage is prevented with green shade cloth wind breaks.
Last, introducing bee keeping within the green shade cloth assist in rapid plant pollination, longer flowering of plants, increase crop yield and harvesting period (longer plant life span). With rapid plant pollination yields are higher without the need for more irrigation.
I also use drip irrigation system and storing water to feed plants through gravitational flow. Drip irrigation prevent leaves diseases caused by long term direct contact of plant leaves and water like pustules, blights, spots and specks as it waters directly to the roots of the plant.
Organic crop protection takes time and work. It is location specific based on climatic conditions, incidence of pests and diseases and ava 
 
Sur quel marché et vers quelle cible 
I have currently identified some of the potential clients within the Agricultural Sector. Especially farmers associations with farmers that specializes in macadamia nuts, avocado and citrus because these commodities are very sensitive and requires a highly efficient, reliable and intelligent tool. All projects that are funded by the Department of Rural Development and Land Reform, Department of Agriculture, Forest and Fisheries, District and Local Municipalities. In most cases there is less extension support offered to beneficiaries, as a results the success percentage for small scale farmers, emerging farmers and co-operatives is very low in agricultural sector. When beneficiaries fail, government losses lot of money and that negatively impact on tax payers. 
 
Zone géographique de l’activité 
Organic crop protection takes time, and can be location specific based on climatic conditions, incidence of pests and diseases and available type of composting material, as such requires lot of steps to be followed to ensure soil is being prepared proper before planting and it is labour intensive but it is worth exploring. The mandate for this proposed idea is to tackle the following key issues facing the country and the continent, food security, unemployment, poverty alleviation and transfer of permaculture skills. 

Organic Crop Protection idea will have positive social impact through addressing problems such as unemployment, poverty, lack of knowledge and less development skills. I have gone through trial and error period and learnt my lessons with that experience I am confident to make this opportunity a success story. I discovered that organic crops protection display best results in yield and market demand.
It is always essential to acquire knowledge and pass it on to benefit oth 
 
Objectifs de croissance et vision à moyen et long terme du marché 
T o be a leading organization in Organic Farming , to obtaining Organic Farming Certificate and to conduct organic trainings. 
 
En quoi votre solution est elle innovante 
I looked at the growing populations in cities and peri-urban areas with limited space for food production and cities are being seen beyond residential infrastructure, and more multi-purpose, which should include agriculture, e.g. the city of Johannesburg is the largest urban forest in the world. Cities generally produce the most waste, which also includes a significant component of organic waste, which eventually pollutes waterways, e.g. higher concentration of nitrates and sulphates in cities due to concentration of consumption.
 The crop production chemicals and fertilisers are generally produced in concentrations around the world and have high carbon footprints, with fertilisers being primarily oil-derived and use a lot of energy to produce. The market for organic produce is growing and sells at a premium, small scale peri-urban farmers could be taught production principles and sell to periodic markets in the cities; e.g. vegetable clubs to which fresh in-season organic vegetables are delivered on specific days. 
 
En quoi est elle duplicable à moindre coût 
The concept is low cost - recycling based organic crop production in cities and peri-urban areas, where principles of organic crop nutrition and organic crop protection are used in a holistic production process. The concept includes the development of a demonstration plot, and exploration of the potential to sell support services and products to aspiring urban and peri-urban farmers.
